results.title: Iron ore
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Joe Scully
results.brief_description: A survey of the mining, transporting and use of iron ore in the steel industry at Whyalla and Port Kembla. Indicates the various unused deposits of iron ore, especially in Western Australia.

results.title: Iron lace
results.brief_description: Shows some of the intricate and delicate designs of wrought iron as seen on homes in Melbourne’s older residential areas.

results.title: Iron Island
results.creator_credit: R.H. Miller and Southern Cross Films
results.brief_description: The winning of iron ore from the earth at Cockatoo Island on Yampi Sound (Western Australia). Recalls the history of the region mentioning the importance of the pearling industry in the earlier part of the century. Shows the amenities provided for the residents of Cockatoo Island; views the extraction of the iron ore; transportation by trucks and conveyor belts to primary and secondary crushing plants; loading of the ore on to ships.

results.title: Iron in Australia
results.brief_description: An instructional film surveying the iron industry in Australia. Shows the mining of iron ore; the processing procedure, using explanatory animated drawings; and the manufacture of iron and steel products. Includes a brief history of the industry in Australia. Commentary by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Irma Vep
results.creator_credit: Georges Benayoun, Dacia Films and Olivier Assayas
results.brief_description: Irma Vep is a charming comedy about the art of filmmaking. When Hong Kong movie star Maggie (Maggie Cheung playing herself) comes to make a film in Paris with French director Rene Vidal(Jean-Pierre Leaud) she has little idea of the maelstrom she is entering. Despite the stresses of being in a strange city with a minimum grasp of the French language, Maggie implicitly believes in her director’s vision. His long-suffering crew, however, do not and when Rene is overcome with the symptoms of a nervous breakdown it seems the film is set for a disasterous outcome. Despite this, “Irma Vep” ends on a magical note as the mysterious director manages to create his vision despite the circumstances of the film-making process. In this fun ‘mockumentary’ Oliver Assayas cryptically comments on the art of filmmaking as well as on the French film industry (and the Hong Kong film phenomenon). Ultimately “Irma Vep” is a vehicle for and a tribute to Hong Kong movie star Maggie Cheung, whose brave performance grounds the whole film. In English and French with English subtitles.

results.title: Irma La Douce
results.creator_credit: Edward Alperson, Mirisch Corporation, Billy Wilder and Orry-Kelly
results.brief_description: Comedy set in the red-light district of Paris, where Irma La Douce (Shirley MacLaine) is a “working girl”. A naive gendarme (Jack Lemmon) falls for the beautiful Irma after conducting a one-man raid on a notorious backstreet establishment. He becomes Irma’s “business manager” but soon becomes insanely jealous of her clientele and in despair, devises a clever way to keep her all to himself. MacLaine and Lemmon display their impressive comic talents under Billy Wilder’s direction. This screen adaptation was based on the successful Broadway musical.

results.title: Irene moves in
results.creator_credit: Playing With Time, Linda Schuyler and Kit Hood
results.brief_description: Ida resents Irene who is a newcomer to the neighbourhood and tries to prevent her from joining the secret club of which she is president. Raises issues about friendships, loyalties, and abuse of power.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Playing With Time, Linda Schuyler and Kit Hood

results.title: Irene
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Imperadio Pictures and Herbert Wilcox
results.brief_description: Based on American playwright James Montgomery’s book of the same name written in 1919, and a remake of the 1926 silent hit, this romantic musical comedy stars Anna Neagle in the lead role of Irene, a poor young Irish girl working in New York and her subsequent involvement with two wealthy men vying for her affection. Stars Ray Milland, Alan Marshal, Roland Young, Billie Burke.

results.title: Ireland
results.creator_credit: Mary Downes, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Changing stages”.
Second episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. This program focuses on Ireland and some of the Irish playwrights who gave birth to a new kind of theatre, one that had more substance than the 19th century Victorian melodrama and moralising society plays which were being performed in Britain, most significantly, at a time when Ireland was fighting for independence from British empirical connections. Richard Eyre discusses in great detail the influences and historical background of several Irish playwrights including William Butler Yeats, George Bernard Shaw, Oscar Wilde, Sean O’Casey, and J.M. Synge and the part these individuals played in the establishment of a national theatre and a national identity for Ireland. Yeats, Shaw and Wilde were all born in Dublin around the same time, but Shaw and Wilde very early on exiled themselves to England to make their fame and fortune through satirising the English high society. In contrast, against a background of political turmoil and tension, Yeats, in collaboration with Lady Augusta Gregory, conceived The Abbey Theatre which was to become Ireland’s national theatre and a stage for the works of Sean O’Casey and J.M. Synge, both playwrights who shared the belief that plays could be about contemporary events and the reality of people’s lives. Contains excerpts from film adaptations and theatrical performances including “The Importance of being Ernest” (Wilde), “The Playboy of the western world” (Synge), “Juno and the paycock” (O’Casey), “Pygmalion” (Shaw), “The Plough and the stars” (O’Casey), “Mrs Warren’s profession” (Shaw) and interviews and conversations with actors and playwrights including Stephen Rea, Liam Neeson, Fiona Shaw, Alan Bennett, Tom Stoppard, Peter Gill, Edna O’Brien and David Hare. Also uses b&w archival footage, stills, and beautiful images of the Irish landscape and seascape. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.

results.title: Ireland
results.brief_description: Class-room instruction film on the land and the people of Ireland. Relates economic life to the cool temperate climate. Shows in some detail the small farms which directly sustain about half the population.
